page.title: 03GEOLOGY OF SELSFIELD AREA
page.content: This is the{Lower Cretaceous}surface of alternating beds of varied clays and sandstones with gentle, mainly westward dipping and occasional west to east faulting. There are several steepsided valleys in which are numerous outcrops of the massive sandstone which forms the upper part of the{Lower Tunbridge Wells Sand}in the western{Weald.}The most imposing examples are in the privately owned {Chiddinglye Wood,}where well-jointed sandstone is slightly cambered so that large rectangular blocks have become separated from the main outcrop by narrow vertical chasms up to 11m deep. Some of the rocks also show under cutting at their base caused by water seepage. A striking example of this is the rock called{Great Upon Little, where a great mass of sandstone over hangs a thin central support.
